elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two distinct Zn(II) coordination polymers (CPs) have been prepared based on Zn(NO3)2 and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (2-Heiba) via different synthetic approaches, solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion, respectively. Upon solvothermal condition, a 2D undulated CP [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)] n  (1) can be obtained, which incorporates the polythreading structural motifs and then results in the 3-fold pcu topological network with the aid of interlayer OH⋯N hydrogen bonds. Employment of layer diffusion method affords another 3D CP {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3} n  (2), featuring a dia topological network in 2+2→4-fold interpenetrating pattern. Interestingly, interconvertible structural transformations between 1 and 2 can be achieved by immersing in CH3OH-H2O solution under stirring or solvothermal conditions, respectively. In addition, thermal stability and fluorescence properties of these complexes have also been studied.

Highlights

   ⋅ Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from ZnII and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.   ⋅ The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.   ⋅ They display 3-fold pcu and 4-fold dia interpenetrating networks.   ⋅ Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.

elements.clean_text:
Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from ZnII and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.

The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.

They display 3-fold pcu and 4-fold dia interpenetrating networks.

Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.

Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)] n  (1) and {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3} n  (2) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively.  1 Synthesis of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)] n  (1). Mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) and 2-Heiba (21.6mg, 0.1mmol) in CH3OH (5mL) and H2O (5mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 100°C for 3days. Colorless block single crystals of 1 were collected by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 15°C/h (yield: 15.6mg). Anal. Calcd for C36H34O7N6Zn2: C,54.49; H,4.32; N,10.59%. Found: C, 54.68; H, 4.29; N, 10.39%. IR (cm-1): 3401m, 3146m, 3058m, 1617vs, 1561m, 1513m, 1466m, 1379vs, 1307w, 1254w, 1176m, 1149w, 1107w, 1053s, 1009w, 960w, 879w, 849m, 788s, 743w, 722m, 644w, 617w, 584w, 547m, 524w, 504w, 458w, 411w. Synthesis of {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3} n  (2). A methanol solution (3mL) of 2-Heiba (21.6mg, 0.1mmol) was carefully layered onto a water solution (3mL) of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) in a glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature after three days (yield: 18.6mg). Anal. Calcd for C24H28N4O7Zn: C, 52.42; H, 5.13; N, 10.19%. Found: C, 52.46; H, 5.18; N, 10.11%. IR (cm-1): 3405b, 1632vs, 1575w, 1510m, 1462m, 1361vs, 1308m, 1251w, 1172m, 1147w, 1110w, 1053s, 1012m, 874w, 843m, 787m, 704m, 574m, 546m, 513m, 442w.  Single-crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that they display different entangled architectures, 3-fold and 2+2→4-fold types, respectively. More interestingly, interconvertible structrual transformations between 1 and 2 can be achieved with intensive rearrangement of the overall crystalline lattice. Thermal stability and fluorescence properties of these complexes have also been studied.

</ce:footnote> is a 2D undulated polymeric layer, which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with <ce:italic>Cm</ce:italic> space group. The asymmetric coordination unit comprises one Zn(II), one and a half independent 2-eiba ligands, and a half-occupied hydroxide ions. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, each Zn(II) is coordinated by four O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands and one hydroxide ion, and one N atom from another 2-eiba ligand. The coordination geometry of the Zn center (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.48) can be portrayed as a distorted polyhedron between trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid, where the τ values of the ideal trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid are defined as 1 and 0, respectively . A pair of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers are interconnected by the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hydroxyl and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> bridges to form a [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)(OH)] secondary building unit (SBU), with the Zn<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>Zn separation of 3.292(2) Å. As for the 2-eiba ligands, they show the bridging and terminal linking role to connect the binuclear Zn(II) SBU, respectively. In this way, a grid-like layered coordination net (14.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), being extended through 2-eiba ligands, is formed (b). This 2D pattern is considerably undulated and of further importance, decorated with the unidentate 2-eiba pendants as side arms at single side. Interestingly, these long prominent arms, with a length of ca.7.824<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the pyridyl N atom and carboxylate C atom, penetrate into the grids of two adjacent layers to build a 3D polythreading supramolecular architecture with finite components . In fact, each lateral 2-eiba arm goes through two parallel grids and forms a O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N hydrogen bond with the third one (O<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.759<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.91<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, ∠<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>172°) (c). Thus, if these H-bonding interactions are also taken into account, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)(OH)] SBUs behave as 6-connected nodes and 2-eiba ligands act as bridges. Then three uniform 3D networks are generated, which are 3-fold interpenetrating (d and e). In view of topological simplification, a single net is isolated and classified as a <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> net .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) study shows that the structure of 1   2 Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically on F  2  for all non-H atoms by full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELXTL. H atoms of the ligands were located geometrically with assigned isotropic thermal parameters. The water molecules in 2 were treated as the diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom sites by SQUEEZE/PLATON. Crystallographic data for 1: C36H34Zn2N6O7, M =793.43, 0.18×0.17×0.15mm3, monoclinic, Cm, a =12.179(4), b =19.368(6), c =7.751(3) Å, β =97.382(8)°, V =1813.2(11) Å3, Z =2, D c =1.453g/cm3, F(000)=816, GOF=1.006, μ =1.379mm-1, R int =0.0246, final R indices [I >2σ(I)] R 1 =0.0244 and wR 2 =0.0526. Crystallographic data for 2: C24H22ZnN4O4, M =495.83, 0.22×0.21×0.17mm3, tetragonal, P4nc, a =14.106(3), b =14.106(3), c =13.972(3) Å, V =2780.1(10) Å3, Z =4, D c =1.185g/cm3, F(000)=1024, GOF=1.074, μ =0.915mm-1, R int =0.0311, final R indices [I >2σ(I)] R 1 =0.0348 and wR 2 =0.0886.  is a 2D undulated polymeric layer, which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with Cm space group. The asymmetric coordination unit comprises one Zn(II), one and a half independent 2-eiba ligands, and a half-occupied hydroxide ions. As shown in a, each Zn(II) is coordinated by four O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands and one hydroxide ion, and one N atom from another 2-eiba ligand. The coordination geometry of the Zn center (τ=0.48) can be portrayed as a distorted polyhedron between trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid, where the τ values of the ideal trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid are defined as 1 and 0, respectively . A pair of ZnII centers are interconnected by the μ2-hydroxyl and μ2-COO- bridges to form a [Zn2(COO)(OH)] secondary building unit (SBU), with the Zn⋯Zn separation of 3.292(2) Å. As for the 2-eiba ligands, they show the bridging and terminal linking role to connect the binuclear Zn(II) SBU, respectively. In this way, a grid-like layered coordination net (14.25×14.25Å2), being extended through 2-eiba ligands, is formed (b). This 2D pattern is considerably undulated and of further importance, decorated with the unidentate 2-eiba pendants as side arms at single side. Interestingly, these long prominent arms, with a length of ca.7.824Å between the pyridyl N atom and carboxylate C atom, penetrate into the grids of two adjacent layers to build a 3D polythreading supramolecular architecture with finite components . In fact, each lateral 2-eiba arm goes through two parallel grids and forms a OH⋯N hydrogen bond with the third one (O⋯N=2.759Å, H⋯N=1.91Å, ∠OH⋯N=172°) (c). Thus, if these H-bonding interactions are also taken into account, [Zn2(COO)(OH)] SBUs behave as 6-connected nodes and 2-eiba ligands act as bridges. Then three uniform 3D networks are generated, which are 3-fold interpenetrating (d and e). In view of topological simplification, a single net is isolated and classified as a pcu net .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">When employing layer diffusion condition, another 3D coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> is achieved, which crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4<ce:italic>nc</ce:italic> space group. In the asymmetric coordination unit, it consists of half crystallographic independent Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> atoms and one independent 2-eiba ligand. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, each Zn(II) is coordinated by two O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, and two N atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, displaying a distorted tetrahedral geometry. In this way, each tetrahedral Zn(II) center is extended by four 2-eiba bridges to form a 3D architecture. This network possesses a channel with dimension of ca. 12.17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, showing a <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> topological pattern (b). Two adjacent nets are entangled with each other in a parallel fashion, to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (c). Further study reveals that two sets of such normal 2-fold interpenetrating nets suffer a [2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2] roto-translation to result in a 4-fold <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> prototype (d and e).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When employing layer diffusion condition, another 3D coordination polymer 2 2 is achieved, which crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with P4nc space group. In the asymmetric coordination unit, it consists of half crystallographic independent ZnII atoms and one independent 2-eiba ligand. As shown in a, each Zn(II) is coordinated by two O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, and two N atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, displaying a distorted tetrahedral geometry. In this way, each tetrahedral Zn(II) center is extended by four 2-eiba bridges to form a 3D architecture. This network possesses a channel with dimension of ca. 12.17×12.17Å2 along the c axis, showing a dia topological pattern (b). Two adjacent nets are entangled with each other in a parallel fashion, to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (c). Further study reveals that two sets of such normal 2-fold interpenetrating nets suffer a [2+2] roto-translation to result in a 4-fold dia prototype (d and e).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In general, self-assembly reaction by varying distinct synthetic approaches could result in kinetic or thermodynamic products, respectively, which may be readily interconvertible . CPs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be obtained from solvothermal and layered diffusion methods, respectively, and thus supposed to be kinetic and thermodynamic products . In order to study the structural transformation behaviors between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, we dipped <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> into CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution under ambient stirring or placed <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> into Teflon-lined autoclave under solvothermal condition. On one hand, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can transform to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at ambient stirring condition after one day, as determined by PXRD patterns (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). During this process, the shapes of crystals kept intact, but SC-XRD studies could not be performed despite repeated attempts, due to weak diffraction. On the other hand, transformation from <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> cannot be achieved only by dipping <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> into solution upon heating. If placing crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in solution under solvothermal condition, white powders are generated which are proved to be <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> through PXRD patterns (b). However, the detailed mechanism of such process cannot be determined due to the black-box effect of solvothermal reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In general, self-assembly reaction by varying distinct synthetic approaches could result in kinetic or thermodynamic products, respectively, which may be readily interconvertible . CPs 1 and 2 can be obtained from solvothermal and layered diffusion methods, respectively, and thus supposed to be kinetic and thermodynamic products . In order to study the structural transformation behaviors between 1 and 2, we dipped 1 into CH3OH-H2O solution under ambient stirring or placed 2 into Teflon-lined autoclave under solvothermal condition. On one hand, 1 can transform to 2 at ambient stirring condition after one day, as determined by PXRD patterns (a). During this process, the shapes of crystals kept intact, but SC-XRD studies could not be performed despite repeated attempts, due to weak diffraction. On the other hand, transformation from 2 to 1 cannot be achieved only by dipping 2 into solution upon heating. If placing crystals of 2 in solution under solvothermal condition, white powders are generated which are proved to be 1 through PXRD patterns (b). However, the detailed mechanism of such process cannot be determined due to the black-box effect of solvothermal reaction.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In the TGA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S2), the framework keeps intact upon heating to 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then suffers a sharp weight loss, which does not cease until heating to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the first weight loss of 10.23% in the range of 35–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, revealing the removal of three water molecules (calculated: 10.89%). The residue starts to decompose with a sharp weight loss between 350 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then the slow weight loss does not end until 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Solid-state fluorescent measurements indicate that excitation of microcrystalline sample of 2-Heiba at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm results in the maximum fluorescent emission at 419<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, while those for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> appear at 436 and 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm under the same condition (Fig. S3). By comparing the locations and profiles of their emission peaks, the significant red-shift (∆<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and different types of emission profiles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to 2-Heiba are found. Obviously, these emissions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are not the intra-ligand π<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π* transitions of the ligand, but can be properly ascribed to either metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT) between the 2-eiba<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the metal centers in the polymeric networks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the TGA curve of 1 (Fig. S2), the framework keeps intact upon heating to 375°C and then suffers a sharp weight loss, which does not cease until heating to 800°C. The TGA curve of 2 shows the first weight loss of 10.23% in the range of 35-240°C, revealing the removal of three water molecules (calculated: 10.89%). The residue starts to decompose with a sharp weight loss between 350 and 450°C, and then the slow weight loss does not end until 800°C. Solid-state fluorescent measurements indicate that excitation of microcrystalline sample of 2-Heiba at 370nm results in the maximum fluorescent emission at 419nm, while those for 1 and 2 appear at 436 and 429nm under the same condition (Fig. S3). By comparing the locations and profiles of their emission peaks, the significant red-shift (∆=17nm for 1 and 10nm for 2) and different types of emission profiles of 1 or 2 to 2-Heiba are found. Obviously, these emissions in 1 and 2 are not the intra-ligand π→π* transitions of the ligand, but can be properly ascribed to either metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT) between the 2-eiba- and the metal centers in the polymeric networks.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">In conclusion, a pair of Zn(II) coordination polymers can be produced from different synthetic routes of solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion, which display the 3-fold interpenetrating <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topological network and 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-fold interpenetrating <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> pattern, respectively. Moreover, interconvertible structural transformations between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be achieved via different reaction conditions. Toward this direction, further investigation on the regulation of structural networks of CPs as well as their transformations is underway in our lab.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a pair of Zn(II) coordination polymers can be produced from different synthetic routes of solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion, which display the 3-fold interpenetrating pcu topological network and 2+2→4-fold interpenetrating dia pattern, respectively. Moreover, interconvertible structural transformations between 1 and 2 can be achieved via different reaction conditions. Toward this direction, further investigation on the regulation of structural networks of CPs as well as their transformations is underway in our lab.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and 4-(2-ethyl-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">They display 3-fold <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> and 4-fold <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> interpenetrating networks.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Zn(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively.
<ce:footnote id="fn0005">
<ce:label>1</ce:label>
<ce:note-para id="np0005" view="all">Synthesis of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>. cln_elements.clean_text:
Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from ZnII and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.

The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.

They display 3-fold pcu and 4-fold dia interpenetrating networks.

Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.

Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)] n  (1) and {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3} n  (2) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively.  1 Synthesis of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)] n  (1). Mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) and 2-Heiba (21.6mg, 0.1mmol) in CH3OH (5mL) and H2O (5mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 100°C for 3days. Colorless block single crystals of 1 were collected by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 15°C/h (yield: 15.6mg). Anal. Calcd for C36H34O7N6Zn2: C,54.49; H,4.32; N,10.59%. Found: C, 54.68; H, 4.29; N, 10.39%. IR (cm-1): 3401m, 3146m, 3058m, 1617vs, 1561m, 1513m, 1466m, 1379vs, 1307w, 1254w, 1176m, 1149w, 1107w, 1053s, 1009w, 960w, 879w, 849m, 788s, 743w, 722m, 644w, 617w, 584w, 547m, 524w, 504w, 458w, 411w. Synthesis of {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3} n  (2). A methanol solution (3mL) of 2-Heiba (21.6mg, 0.1mmol) was carefully layered onto a water solution (3mL) of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) in a glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature after three days (yield: 18.6mg). Anal. Calcd for C24H28N4O7Zn: C, 52.42; H, 5.13; N, 10.19%. Found: C, 52.46; H, 5.18; N, 10.11%. IR (cm-1): 3405b, 1632vs, 1575w, 1510m, 1462m, 1361vs, 1308m, 1251w, 1172m, 1147w, 1110w, 1053s, 1012m, 874w, 843m, 787m, 704m, 574m, 546m, 513m, 442w.  Single-crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that they display different entangled architectures, 3-fold and 2+2→4-fold types, respectively. More interestingly, interconvertible structrual transformations between 1 and 2 can be achieved with intensive rearrangement of the overall crystalline lattice. Thermal stability and fluorescence properties of these complexes have also been studied.

</ce:footnote> is a 2D undulated polymeric layer, which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with <ce:italic>Cm</ce:italic> space group. The asymmetric coordination unit comprises one Zn(II), one and a half independent 2-eiba ligands, and a half-occupied hydroxide ions. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, each Zn(II) is coordinated by four O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands and one hydroxide ion, and one N atom from another 2-eiba ligand. The coordination geometry of the Zn center (τ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.48) can be portrayed as a distorted polyhedron between trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid, where the τ values of the ideal trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid are defined as 1 and 0, respectively . A pair of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers are interconnected by the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hydroxyl and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> bridges to form a [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)(OH)] secondary building unit (SBU), with the Zn<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>Zn separation of 3.292(2) Å. As for the 2-eiba ligands, they show the bridging and terminal linking role to connect the binuclear Zn(II) SBU, respectively. In this way, a grid-like layered coordination net (14.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), being extended through 2-eiba ligands, is formed (b). This 2D pattern is considerably undulated and of further importance, decorated with the unidentate 2-eiba pendants as side arms at single side. Interestingly, these long prominent arms, with a length of ca.7.824<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the pyridyl N atom and carboxylate C atom, penetrate into the grids of two adjacent layers to build a 3D polythreading supramolecular architecture with finite components . In fact, each lateral 2-eiba arm goes through two parallel grids and forms a O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N hydrogen bond with the third one (O<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.759<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.91<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, ∠<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>172°) (c). Thus, if these H-bonding interactions are also taken into account, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)(OH)] SBUs behave as 6-connected nodes and 2-eiba ligands act as bridges. Then three uniform 3D networks are generated, which are 3-fold interpenetrating (d and e). In view of topological simplification, a single net is isolated and classified as a <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> net .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">When employing layer diffusion condition, another 3D coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> is achieved, which crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4<ce:italic>nc</ce:italic> space group. In the asymmetric coordination unit, it consists of half crystallographic independent Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> atoms and one independent 2-eiba ligand. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, each Zn(II) is coordinated by two O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, and two N atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, displaying a distorted tetrahedral geometry. In this way, each tetrahedral Zn(II) center is extended by four 2-eiba bridges to form a 3D architecture. This network possesses a channel with dimension of ca. 12.17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, showing a <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> topological pattern (b). Two adjacent nets are entangled with each other in a parallel fashion, to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (c). Further study reveals that two sets of such normal 2-fold interpenetrating nets suffer a [2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2] roto-translation to result in a 4-fold <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> prototype (d and e).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In the TGA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S2), the framework keeps intact upon heating to 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then suffers a sharp weight loss, which does not cease until heating to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the first weight loss of 10.23% in the range of 35–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, revealing the removal of three water molecules (calculated: 10.89%). The residue starts to decompose with a sharp weight loss between 350 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then the slow weight loss does not end until 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Solid-state fluorescent measurements indicate that excitation of microcrystalline sample of 2-Heiba at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm results in the maximum fluorescent emission at 419<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, while those for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> appear at 436 and 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm under the same condition (Fig. S3). By comparing the locations and profiles of their emission peaks, the significant red-shift (∆<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and different types of emission profiles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to 2-Heiba are found. Obviously, these emissions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are not the intra-ligand π<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π* transitions of the ligand, but can be properly ascribed to either metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT) between the 2-eiba<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the metal centers in the polymeric networks.</ce:para>

Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) study shows that the structure of 1   2 Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically on F  2  for all non-H atoms by full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELXTL. H atoms of the ligands were located geometrically with assigned isotropic thermal parameters. The water molecules in 2 were treated as the diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom sites by SQUEEZE/PLATON. Crystallographic data for 1: C36H34Zn2N6O7, M =793.43, 0.18×0.17×0.15mm3, monoclinic, Cm, a =12.179(4), b =19.368(6), c =7.751(3) Å, β =97.382(8)°, V =1813.2(11) Å3, Z =2, D c =1.453g/cm3, F(000)=816, GOF=1.006, μ =1.379mm-1, R int =0.0246, final R indices [I >2σ(I)] R 1 =0.0244 and wR 2 =0.0526. Crystallographic data for 2: C24H22ZnN4O4, M =495.83, 0.22×0.21×0.17mm3, tetragonal, P4nc, a =14.106(3), b =14.106(3), c =13.972(3) Å, V =2780.1(10) Å3, Z =4, D c =1.185g/cm3, F(000)=1024, GOF=1.074, μ =0.915mm-1, R int =0.0311, final R indices [I >2σ(I)] R 1 =0.0348 and wR 2 =0.0886.  is a 2D undulated polymeric layer, which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with Cm space group. The asymmetric coordination unit comprises one Zn(II), one and a half independent 2-eiba ligands, and a half-occupied hydroxide ions. As shown in a, each Zn(II) is coordinated by four O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands and one hydroxide ion, and one N atom from another 2-eiba ligand. The coordination geometry of the Zn center (τ=0.48) can be portrayed as a distorted polyhedron between trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid, where the τ values of the ideal trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid are defined as 1 and 0, respectively . A pair of ZnII centers are interconnected by the μ2-hydroxyl and μ2-COO- bridges to form a [Zn2(COO)(OH)] secondary building unit (SBU), with the Zn⋯Zn separation of 3.292(2) Å. As for the 2-eiba ligands, they show the bridging and terminal linking role to connect the binuclear Zn(II) SBU, respectively. In this way, a grid-like layered coordination net (14.25×14.25Å2), being extended through 2-eiba ligands, is formed (b). This 2D pattern is considerably undulated and of further importance, decorated with the unidentate 2-eiba pendants as side arms at single side. Interestingly, these long prominent arms, with a length of ca.7.824Å between the pyridyl N atom and carboxylate C atom, penetrate into the grids of two adjacent layers to build a 3D polythreading supramolecular architecture with finite components . In fact, each lateral 2-eiba arm goes through two parallel grids and forms a OH⋯N hydrogen bond with the third one (O⋯N=2.759Å, H⋯N=1.91Å, ∠OH⋯N=172°) (c). Thus, if these H-bonding interactions are also taken into account, [Zn2(COO)(OH)] SBUs behave as 6-connected nodes and 2-eiba ligands act as bridges. Then three uniform 3D networks are generated, which are 3-fold interpenetrating (d and e). In view of topological simplification, a single net is isolated and classified as a pcu net .

When employing layer diffusion condition, another 3D coordination polymer 2 2 is achieved, which crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with P4nc space group. In the asymmetric coordination unit, it consists of half crystallographic independent ZnII atoms and one independent 2-eiba ligand. As shown in a, each Zn(II) is coordinated by two O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, and two N atoms from two 2-eiba ligands, displaying a distorted tetrahedral geometry. In this way, each tetrahedral Zn(II) center is extended by four 2-eiba bridges to form a 3D architecture. This network possesses a channel with dimension of ca. 12.17×12.17Å2 along the c axis, showing a dia topological pattern (b). Two adjacent nets are entangled with each other in a parallel fashion, to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (c). Further study reveals that two sets of such normal 2-fold interpenetrating nets suffer a [2+2] roto-translation to result in a 4-fold dia prototype (d and e).

In the TGA curve of 1 (Fig. S2), the framework keeps intact upon heating to 375°C and then suffers a sharp weight loss, which does not cease until heating to 800°C. The TGA curve of 2 shows the first weight loss of 10.23% in the range of 35-240°C, revealing the removal of three water molecules (calculated: 10.89%). The residue starts to decompose with a sharp weight loss between 350 and 450°C, and then the slow weight loss does not end until 800°C. Solid-state fluorescent measurements indicate that excitation of microcrystalline sample of 2-Heiba at 370nm results in the maximum fluorescent emission at 419nm, while those for 1 and 2 appear at 436 and 429nm under the same condition (Fig. S3). By comparing the locations and profiles of their emission peaks, the significant red-shift (∆=17nm for 1 and 10nm for 2) and different types of emission profiles of 1 or 2 to 2-Heiba are found. Obviously, these emissions in 1 and 2 are not the intra-ligand π→π* transitions of the ligand, but can be properly ascribed to either metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT) between the 2-eiba- and the metal centers in the polymeric networks.
